We have lately received ON our correspondent
? e OF Buenos Ayrcs newspapers, which are al
most exclusively occupied with matter relating to
the rejected treaty.


Since the disavowal of the treaty formed with
Brazil by Garciain absolute con radictIon to his
ia, lructons, this Republic has been in a state ul the
greatest excitement and confusion. The President.
RvlDAviA, resigned his office in letter. expressive
of his belief that the best interests of his country
qured the appointment of successor who might
administer 'he government with less opposition from
personal enemies. His resignation was accepted by
Congress Justice being rendered to the motives
which dictated the sacrifice on his part. According
" D. Vicente Lopez was appointed. by majority
Of 81 votes over several candidates. provisional
President of Buenns Ayres. This honor involving
in it so many artluous duties, respectfully de
clined but on the following day, a5r the reslgna-
on was read, Congress proceeded to new election.
when it appeared that the result was the same and
the fact being announced to Lopez, he accepted the
Presidency until the reunion of the National Con-
vention. and the pacilicaton of the Provinces Al
ter receiving the oath of Office, the President appon
ted D Julian $. ID. Aguero, Minister Of Govern
ment and Landed Property Gen. Thomas Guido.
Minister Of war: d. Manual Dorego. Minister of
Marine and and foreign Relations These gentle
men have since resigned the situations to which they
were named. Brlsadier General i.avalleja is APP
oned General in Chief of the Republican Army.


Great anxiety is expressed to turn the tide OF emf
grafton from other countries towards Buenos Ayres
to fill the void in their population. 1t is stated that,
with all their efforts and appropriations OF money,
agricultural implements, merIn0 sheep &C. they have
only obtained an increase of 1917 individuals in two
years, while in New York, whose climate and fer
tility cannot compare with theirs. there was an
accession of 2l5O foreigners in one week OF the
year 1918. This difference they attributed to the
spectacle of orer tranquility, andsyood faith, which
our country presents to all nations.


The following are the concluding articles unanlm-
ously adopted by Congress in July: -.


Article ,2ih. The President will employ all his
efforts in the manner which his prudence may sug,
gest to put an end to civil war; for which purpose all
necessary means will be authorized.


Article 18th. The great object of national war,
and the adoption of the most eliicacons and enege-
ic means to carry it into effect is particularly re-
commended TO the new President, in order that all
the People may concur in such manner as the ho-
or of the Republic inperousy demands

From the National lnteMgencer


RIJENOS AYRGS.

At this period OF the autumn. we may safely con-
gratulae our readers ON one of the most healthy
seasons that have occurred here for a long time.
Both town and country, we have mentioned, here
toiore, have been comparatively exempt from the
scourge of autumnal diseases incidental to the ct,-
mate. In town, more especially, the bill of morta|i-
t. has shrunk far within its usual limits. At the same
time. the harvests have been abundant. and vegeta-
ti,D generally uxurant.-a circumstance usually
deemed unlriendy to salubriousness. The sun now
shines with tempered ray. the morning breeze has
already the freshness of October, and man can
make transition. from the sun to the shade. with
out risk Of rheumatism, or of disturbing the bile.
The very ladies' are seen sometimes undergoing the
fatigue of a walk

400 or three days previous to the election on the 9th
inst. Notwithstanding, the Philadelphians were
such simpIetons as to express their appreciation of
the Administration by the election Of John Sergeant
three days after it appeared in print Since that
time, it has travelled to New York, and been served
up to all good Jacksontes in that city


On this subject, the New York American re-
Marks "On Wednesday we ventured to pro-
nouuce this story to be false, both from its in
trinsic improbaoty. and from the high character it
was intended to implcate."


As to the two nelnbers ufCongrcss, whose names
are left as vouchers for the truth of the story told by
the Palladium, we cannot say that passes for much
Wuh us. We know more than two members OF
Consress, whose testimony upon any pnnt connect
ed with the a. atng political question of the day,
would not weigh with us feather !; for NJ. G. writ
ten AFTER a name can no more confer responsibility
of character. or discrimination of mind, than de-
gree Of l.. d. confer legal learning


We are now enabled To state upon the highest az
fhority, that this story, by whunsoever told, or by
whomsoever vouched for, is utterly untrue. and cith
cut shadotc Of foundation. 10 the base natures
tat have inven,ed and circulated this foul lie, we
leave the task Of vindcating themselves before the
public.

Pennsylvania Elcctions.-Our accounts of them
are, indeed, most unexpectedly encouraging. The
success of MIR. Sergeant, in Il district where the
Jackson organ has said " ii would be satisfied with
nothing less than one thousand majority for Mr.
Hemphill,' was the first blow TO the hopes Of the
combination---bu then they consoed themselves by
saving, that the Congressional district embraced on
" twelve out of the fifteen wards Of the city, but
that, if the whole city had voted, the result would
have been different. Unfortunately for this posi-
ton, the majority of Mr.. John Hare Powell, the ad-
minstration candidate for the Senate, was in the
whole city, 328-whie that OF Mr.. Sergeant, in the
twelve wards was 157--so that the other wards
would have added to, nsteao of diminishing his tna-
jority.

Domestic MauJactures. The attention Of the
public is directed to the sale of five hundred pieces

We can put the whole State in onr breeches pocket.

The Richmond, (Va.) Wing of Saturday last,
speaking OF the proposed Anti-Jackson Convention,
says


1--WE have cheering accounts from many parts OF
the State, that the people are beginning to think and
act for themselves, and arc ready to put an end 10
the degradation of being dictated to by the metro
politan dcmagogues, who have SO long enjoyed the
honour of conrolng the politics OF the State. They
do not choose to have their rights further usurped
by a few individuals in Richmond, who have tor IA
series of years issued their rescrps with imperial
consequence An important crisis It Is seen has oc-
Cured in our political affairs and the sell constl-
tuted agents o our citizens about to be dlsrob-
ell Of their despotic sway. Meetings nave a'reany
heen held in Frederick, Lancaster Loudoun' otai-
ford, and King George, and delegates appointed 70
attend the nun in this city, on ihe oth OF an
uary next --and we understand that meetings Tor
the same purpose are called in the counties oil JET
farson, Hampshire, Hardy, Caroline, Ric',nood'
Wes,moreland, Powhatan. Berkley Augusta, Rock
bridge, Lynchburg, Campbell, Cumberland, LOUISA
Chesterfield, Goochland, and Hanover. III this
city, Il meeting is proposed 10 be held in shor
time. when triumphant majority of the administra
ti,n will be demonstrated, men of talent and stand
Ing in society. Let the friends of the ,admlnlsra
ton therefore, not be disheartened by the clamour
of their opponrn's.--Our enemies it is true, are
predicting our defeat. Let them predict, but let III
act, The impetus which has been given TO thu
Convention bali is only gaining strength aud will


the necessary information of the merits of the con


royersv, new vigor will be infused into the people
and new cxertions will be made to save themselve
from the threatened danger of military n'isrule

From The NeU-Hampshire Journal:

last act of enc of The most Savage, barbarous scenes
ever saw or heard of in my life, On anchofingih
the small bay, on the north east end, we found the
Inhabitants had all fed, leaving few pigs sheep OF
goats, behind, to guard the miserable huts. 10.
wards noon, two canoes ventnred from The lee side
Of the Island. After great caution they came along
side, and related the following, in English, thvst, iii
deed all OF them. knowing the language. They stat.
ed that, fortnight before, brig, under Spanish
coulours, from and belonging to Havana, had ans
chored for refreshments, supposed to have had about
80 men, indherently armed. The Capt. requested
the Governor to give his crew mouse to carry On
trade, which was readily granted, taken possession
of, and barter, for small fowls, pigs. and goats car
ried on amicably for two days, when the Spahar,ls
real had not on the Island. On the following day
two men we're taken on board the brig, and most
verely beaten they are since dead. The Natives
now fled to the mountains for safety. On the third
day some returned, and the kindness OF the captain
and his crew, for the time, induced all to return 10
the village. Four Of the crew slept on shore, had
good house or hut, and, as they stated. wers Well
used. On Saturday morning trading continued till
| noon, when the crew rushed OH shore, armed, and
without the least cause. reason, notice. cOmmenc-
ed heavy fire Of musketry upon the poor, harms
less, and Totally de1pnceless inhabitants the cons
sequences Of their firing, as you may suppose, was
dreadful massacre. The inhabitants that were for.
tunate enough, again sought shelter in the mum.
talns, when the unnatural Spanards plun3ered the
village, set fire to it, and burned it completely down,
destroying every article that could be useful.


81 cannot describe the state in which found
these poor beings going shore l saw at least
fifty new graves in and around the church. which
showed the number that had been committed !; and
not family but had lost member, either dying or
dreaufuly woun,ed. myself dressed the wounds
Of ffteen.--My ships medicine chest afforded but d
scant supply however, they were grateful we cut
up shirts. hankerchefs, &c for tlier use. The
number of sufferers killed and woun ded must have
been, at least, 70 or 80. some were burnt with the
houses when wounded, aud others thrown into the
sea by the SpaAiards.

abouiing i'll fruit; tile land lofty 80 miles in circuncr
The inhabitants chiefly descendan from Por
tgucse and Christian negroes. has containing
about 90 houses Pop. 5UU. Lat l. 81, s. Lo s, 49, E.

President Adams arrived yesterday morning in
the steam boat Burlington, from New York. He
was heartily greeted on his arrival, and also on en-
terng the Mansion House, Mr.. Heads Hotel,
opened on the 10th inst.) his present lodging.


He was visited about noon by the Mayor city
councils, and very large number Of citizens. He
declined accepting in invitation to the Chesnut St.
Theatre this evening.


This morning he will hear Mr.. Binneys eu!ogium
on the late Chief Justice Tilghnan. He will leave
the city for Washington in the Baltimore steam
boat, this day, at II o'clock precisely.

have seen in the New York Evening Post Of the
9th inst. a paragraph extracted from the Phddel-
pha Palladium OF the 9th, alleging, IN express terms,

tia election, had conversations with Mr. Webster
and Mr.. Adams, the consideration which tie ede-

ernmen offices, If MIR. Il. should be made President;

Every part Of these allegations is gross tabrca-
tion utterly destitute ofthe shadow of truth new
er mad ti;t!e OF any such lt!on with either
Mr.. A. or Mr.. w. nor did amy letter ever pass
from or through me, having the most remote resenl-

uublasling ialsehoods From the date of the pub

Comments on such prolligcy is unnecessary.

The result Of the late elections in Maryland,
Delaware, Pcnnsy ylvania, and New Jersey, is sad
omen of the prospects of General Jackson The
changes in favour of the Administration are prin-
eipallv in PENNSYLVANIA, the other States having

qnte so stupid their iabricatons seem to sup

some particulars respecting the elections nPennsyl


vania will be given hereafter. From the Potomac

order and good government.

From the New York Daily Advertiser.


10 THE PUBLIC.

In 1924 the majority for Jackson in the City of
Baltimore, was 9OO.--ln 1927 the majority was
466-ln 1924, there were 69O8 votes given. In
1897, there we're 1887. The number ofvotes have
increased 879, while the Jackson majority has de-
creased 434. In Baltimore county the decrease of
Jacksonltes has been still greater In Washington
county, the decrease has been several hundred. In
Frederick, where Jackson had large MA ority in
1894, 1t is now believed that Albums is the strongest
Of the two. And in Allegany, The great jackson hold
in 1894, the Administration has, at this time, dec-
ded and growing najority. Until few days past, it
has been generally admitted that Jackson would get
two electoral votes in the State but it is pret-
ty well ascertaned, that, the whole eleven will be
given for Adams.
From the alexandria Gazette.

The following extract of letter from respecta-
Bile correspondent furnishes satisfactory assurances
that the threatened hustilities with our Northwes-
tern Indies will, in all probability be averted, by
the surrender, their part, Of the murderers Of our
citizens


'On Monday following the Sd September Wan
mig suoth- kan. or the Red Bind and Wee kaw, or
the Sun, came in at Prairie du Chen, accompanied
by one hundred and fourteen of the principal men Of
The ceremonies attending the surrender Of the Red
Bird, carrying in his hand white flag, and two of
his chiefs an American flag each. and his death sons
as sung by himself, were ali very imposing The
Keb Bird shot and scaIped Gaguier-and Weekaw
scalpeu the child These are the outlases commit
ted here and these the persons guilty Of them"
Not. Iat.

most exclusively occupied with matter relating to
the rejected treaty.


Since the disavowal of the treaty formed with
Brazil by Garciain absolute con radictIon to his
ia, lructons, this Republic has been in a state ul the
greatest excitement and confusion. The President.
RvlDAviA, resigned his office in letter. expressive
of his belief that the best interests of his country
qured the appointment of successor who might
administer 'he government with less opposition from
personal enemies. His resignation was accepted by
Congress Justice being rendered to the motives
which dictated the sacrifice on his part. According
" D. Vicente Lopez was appointed. by majority

President of Buenns Ayres. This honor involving
in it so many artluous duties, respectfully de
clined but on the following day, a5r the reslgna-

when it appeared that the result was the same and

vention. and the pacilicaton of the Provinces Al

ted D Julian $. ID. Aguero, Minister Of Govern
ment and Landed Property Gen. Thomas Guido.
Minister Of war: d. Manual Dorego. Minister of

men have since resigned the situations to which they

400 or three days previous to the election on the 9th
inst. Notwithstanding, the Philadelphians were
such simpIetons as to express their appreciation of
the Administration by the election Of John Sergeant
three days after it appeared in print Since that
time, it has travelled to New York, and been served
up to all good Jacksontes in that city


On this subject, the New York American re-
Marks "On Wednesday we ventured to pro-
nouuce this story to be false, both from its in
trinsic improbaoty. and from the high character it
was intended to implcate."


As to the two nelnbers ufCongrcss, whose names
are left as vouchers for the truth of the story told by
the Palladium, we cannot say that passes for much
Wuh us. We know more than two members OF
Consress, whose testimony upon any pnnt connect
ed with the a. atng political question of the day,
would not weigh with us feather !; for NJ. G. writ
ten AFTER a name can no more confer responsibility
of character. or discrimination of mind, than de-
gree Of l.. d. confer legal learning


We are now enabled To state upon the highest az
fhority, that this story, by whunsoever told, or by
whomsoever vouched for, is utterly untrue. and cith
cut shadotc Of foundation. 10 the base natures
tat have inven,ed and circulated this foul lie, we
leave the task Of vindcating themselves before the
public.

full articles.headline: From the NeaU York american.
full articles.article:
Pennsylvania Elcctions.-Our accounts of them
are, indeed, most unexpectedly encouraging. The
success of MIR. Sergeant, in Il district where the
Jackson organ has said " ii would be satisfied with
nothing less than one thousand majority for Mr.
Hemphill,' was the first blow TO the hopes Of the
combination---bu then they consoed themselves by
saving, that the Congressional district embraced on
" twelve out of the fifteen wards Of the city, but
that, if the whole city had voted, the result would
have been different. Unfortunately for this posi-
ton, the majority of Mr.. John Hare Powell, the ad-
minstration candidate for the Senate, was in the
whole city, 328-whie that OF Mr.. Sergeant, in the
twelve wards was 157--so that the other wards
would have added to, nsteao of diminishing his tna-
jority.

full articles.headline: From the Baltimore Patriot.
full articles.article:
Domestic MauJactures. The attention Of the
public is directed to the sale of five hundred pieces
Of Cloths. Cassimeres and Saltinets, manufactured
by our fellow citizen, JAMES SYKES. which takes
place tomorrow morning at 10 O'Clock, at NO.
Hanover street. From those we have seen here
toiore of the same gentleman's manufacture. we
feel authorized to say that these cloths will do cred
it to our country, and afford tie best evidence
of the benefcient effects OF the AMERICAN Sys-
TEM."

We can put the whole State in onr breeches pocket.

full articles.headline: CONVENTION in RICHMOND.
full articles.article:
The Richmond, (Va.) Wing of Saturday last,
speaking OF the proposed Anti-Jackson Convention,
says


1--WE have cheering accounts from many parts OF
the State, that the people are beginning to think and
act for themselves, and arc ready to put an end 10
the degradation of being dictated to by the metro
politan dcmagogues, who have SO long enjoyed the
honour of conrolng the politics OF the State. They
do not choose to have their rights further usurped
by a few individuals in Richmond, who have tor IA
series of years issued their rescrps with imperial
consequence An important crisis It Is seen has oc-
Cured in our political affairs and the sell constl-
tuted agents o our citizens about to be dlsrob-
ell Of their despotic sway. Meetings nave a'reany
heen held in Frederick, Lancaster Loudoun' otai-
ford, and King George, and delegates appointed 70
attend the nun in this city, on ihe oth OF an
uary next --and we understand that meetings Tor
the same purpose are called in the counties oil JET
farson, Hampshire, Hardy, Caroline, Ric',nood'
Wes,moreland, Powhatan. Berkley Augusta, Rock
bridge, Lynchburg, Campbell, Cumberland, LOUISA
Chesterfield, Goochland, and Hanover. III this
city, Il meeting is proposed 10 be held in shor
time. when triumphant majority of the administra
ti,n will be demonstrated, men of talent and stand
Ing in society. Let the friends of the ,admlnlsra
ton therefore, not be disheartened by the clamour
of their opponrn's.--Our enemies it is true, are
predicting our defeat. Let them predict, but let III
act, The impetus which has been given TO thu
Convention bali is only gaining strength aud will


the necessary information of the merits of the con


royersv, new vigor will be infused into the people
and new cxertions will be made to save themselve
from the threatened danger of military n'isrule

full articles.headline: From The NeU-Hampshire Journal:
full articles.article:
We repeat it, because wish it to be kept Id
mind, that the Hon. "prihter for the people; who
contends 50 Justly that Mr. ADAMS must be put downs
because lie not The choice Of the people, or was
very anxious for the election Of Crawford by Cons
gress, notwithstanding ADKINS had nearly three times

But times are changed.

last act of enc of The most Savage, barbarous scenes
ever saw or heard of in my life, On anchofingih
the small bay, on the north east end, we found the
Inhabitants had all fed, leaving few pigs sheep OF
goats, behind, to guard the miserable huts. 10.
wards noon, two canoes ventnred from The lee side
Of the Island. After great caution they came along
side, and related the following, in English, thvst, iii
deed all OF them. knowing the language. They stat.
ed that, fortnight before, brig, under Spanish
coulours, from and belonging to Havana, had ans
chored for refreshments, supposed to have had about
80 men, indherently armed. The Capt. requested
the Governor to give his crew mouse to carry On
trade, which was readily granted, taken possession
of, and barter, for small fowls, pigs. and goats car
ried on amicably for two days, when the Spahar,ls
real had not on the Island. On the following day
two men we're taken on board the brig, and most
verely beaten they are since dead. The Natives
now fled to the mountains for safety. On the third
day some returned, and the kindness OF the captain
and his crew, for the time, induced all to return 10
the village. Four Of the crew slept on shore, had
good house or hut, and, as they stated. wers Well
used. On Saturday morning trading continued till
| noon, when the crew rushed OH shore, armed, and
without the least cause. reason, notice. cOmmenc-
ed heavy fire Of musketry upon the poor, harms
less, and Totally de1pnceless inhabitants the cons
sequences Of their firing, as you may suppose, was
dreadful massacre. The inhabitants that were for.
tunate enough, again sought shelter in the mum.
talns, when the unnatural Spanards plun3ered the
village, set fire to it, and burned it completely down,
destroying every article that could be useful.


81 cannot describe the state in which found
these poor beings going shore l saw at least
fifty new graves in and around the church. which
showed the number that had been committed !; and
not family but had lost member, either dying or
dreaufuly woun,ed. myself dressed the wounds
Of ffteen.--My ships medicine chest afforded but d
scant supply however, they were grateful we cut
up shirts. hankerchefs, &c for tlier use. The
number of sufferers killed and woun ded must have
been, at least, 70 or 80. some were burnt with the
houses when wounded, aud others thrown into the
sea by the SpaAiards.

full articles.headline: THE WEST INDIA TRADE.
full articles.article:
The Philadelphia Press Of Tuesday in remark
ing upon the reasoning of the Philadelph Gazette.
about the loss OF the Westlnda trade, has this par
agraph:


A single fact overthrows ' his abstract rt"son-
ing, and puts his statement into " Pi:" We have
since the loss of the W. AadiU direct trade, EXPORT
ED MORE to the West Indies than we did in the
corresponding months oil the last year, When the
trade was open. We speak from authority-the
authority of the Custom House books.'

full articles.headline: From tie United States Gazette, Oct. t3.
full articles.article:
President Adams arrived yesterday morning in
the steam boat Burlington, from New York. He
was heartily greeted on his arrival, and also on en-
terng the Mansion House, Mr.. Heads Hotel,
opened on the 10th inst.) his present lodging.


He was visited about noon by the Mayor city
councils, and very large number Of citizens. He
declined accepting in invitation to the Chesnut St.
Theatre this evening.


This morning he will hear Mr.. Binneys eu!ogium
on the late Chief Justice Tilghnan. He will leave
the city for Washington in the Baltimore steam
boat, this day, at II o'clock precisely.

full articles.headline: From the Lafourche Gazette.
full articles.article:
DONALDSON, SEPT. S.--'rhe Lqf1urche Gazette
will hencetorward be devoted to the support Of the
.administrotion Of the General Government This
we have been induced to adop'. after mature
reflection, considering the interest Of Louisiana, in
particular, we'll as that of the Union at large de-
pendent, in great degree. upon continuance and
support of the system Of national policy pursued by
the present administration, aud, as inseparaby con
necIed with it, the reelection of Nj. ADAMS 10 the
Office he now so ably fills. Our views on the sr'.sct
will be stated more particularly hereafter.

full articles.headline:
From the New York Daily Advertiser.


10 THE PUBLIC.
full articles.article:
have seen in the New York Evening Post Of the
9th inst. a paragraph extracted from the Phddel-
pha Palladium OF the 9th, alleging, IN express terms,
that in the winter of l82l-J pending the Preslden-
tia election, had conversations with Mr. Webster
and Mr.. Adams, the consideration which tie ede-
raj party would have in the distribution OF the gov
ernmen offices, If MIR. Il. should be made President;
and that letter was written by ME to Mr.. Webster
on the subject, the result OF conversation with
Mr.. Adams, and on his authority.


Every part Of these allegations is gross tabrca-
tion utterly destitute ofthe shadow of truth new
er mad ti;t!e OF any such lt!on with either
Mr.. A. or Mr.. w. nor did amy letter ever pass
from or through me, having the most remote resenl-
bldnce to the one alleged.


Ii is stated, that : tie names Of two gentlemen,
members OF Congress, are left with US he palla-
diuin as warrant ior the above Stetncnt. Ii Is
not possible that this assertion is true. 1t cannot be
that il single member should be found, SO proillgac
aud base as TO give his name rs Il voucher for such
uublasling ialsehoods From the date of the pub
lcaon, three days before the Pennsy lvana election,
ana tron the conspicuous use of the name OF Mr..
Sergeant who vas a candidate ut that election, the
conclusion is inevitable, that The paragraph, is the
fabrication OF some unprinciped partzan, for the
purpose Of giving tempo rary success TO his party
Comments on such prolligcy is unnecessary.
JOHN BAILEY.
Dorchester, Mass. Oct. IL, 1927.


The result Of the late elections in Maryland,
Delaware, Pcnnsy ylvania, and New Jersey, is sad
omen of the prospects of General Jackson The
changes in favour of the Administration are prin-
eipallv in PENNSYLVANIA, the other States having
noyer manifested 50 great partiality for him.


The tales which have so constantly proceeded
from thn Jackson manufactures (almos the only
manufactures which they seem TO cnconrage) have
| prove to be losing concern. The people are mol


qnte so stupid their iabricatons seem to sup


pose and happen in great and growing numbers


to be able to draw the us distinction between thu


interests Of few politicians and the nation 1T large


some particulars respecting the elections nPennsyl


vania will be given hereafter. From the Potomac


to New York the people have decided in favour Q


order and good government.

full articles.headline: From the alexandria Gazette.
full articles.article:
In 1924 the majority for Jackson in the City of
Baltimore, was 9OO.--ln 1927 the majority was
466-ln 1924, there were 69O8 votes given. In
1897, there we're 1887. The number ofvotes have
increased 879, while the Jackson majority has de-
creased 434. In Baltimore county the decrease of
Jacksonltes has been still greater In Washington
county, the decrease has been several hundred. In
Frederick, where Jackson had large MA ority in
1894, 1t is now believed that Albums is the strongest
Of the two. And in Allegany, The great jackson hold
in 1894, the Administration has, at this time, dec-
ded and growing najority. Until few days past, it
has been generally admitted that Jackson would get
two electoral votes in the State but it is pret-
ty well ascertaned, that, the whole eleven will be
given for Adams.

The following extract of letter from respecta-
Bile correspondent furnishes satisfactory assurances
that the threatened hustilities with our Northwes-
tern Indies will, in all probability be averted, by
the surrender, their part, Of the murderers Of our
citizens


'On Monday following the Sd September Wan
mig suoth- kan. or the Red Bind and Wee kaw, or
the Sun, came in at Prairie du Chen, accompanied
by one hundred and fourteen of the principal men Of
The ceremonies attending the surrender Of the Red
Bird, carrying in his hand white flag, and two of
his chiefs an American flag each. and his death sons
as sung by himself, were ali very imposing The
Keb Bird shot and scaIped Gaguier-and Weekaw
scalpeu the child These are the outlases commit
ted here and these the persons guilty Of them"
Not. Iat.
